payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Musu

texts.en: Musu is 30 years old and married with two children. Her main business is selling dried fish in an open air market of Kabala in Sierra Leone.  Musu usually buys fish from the coastal areas and transports them to Kabala. She has been very successful over the years in her fish business but still needs additional capital to purchase larger quantities of fish. By buying in bulk, she can cut down on the number of trips she has to make from the coast to Kabala, which will reduce her transportation costs and help earn more profits. She says that a loan of $600 will make her dreams come true.

loans.use: Fulfill her dreams of earning an adequate income by purchasing additional quantities of dried fish to sell in Kabala.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Yusufu

texts.en: Yusufu is 20 years old and married with a child.  He sells lubricants and with his previous loans, has purchased local products such as palm oil, which he sells to the market women of Magburaka town in Sierra Leone. With the profits from his sales business, Yusufu is now capable of taking good care of his family by providing for their basic needs and other expenses. He is very determined to expand his business by purchasing fuel and lubricants wholesale.  Yusufu is requesting a $350 loan with to expand his business as planned.

loans.use: To diversify his business by starting to offer fuel and lubricants at his general store.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed K. is 21 years old and single. He dropped out of school after the death of his father, and had to take over as his family's main breadwinner by starting a micro business at an early age. Mohamed sells watches, small tape recorders, radios etc. and has used previous loans to buy more products and diversify the range of goods he sells.

With the income from his electronics business, he is able to take care of his mother and pay his younger sisters' school fees. The previous loans also improved his family's status and standard of living. Mohamed would like to expand his business and is requesting an $850 loan for the purpose.

loans.use: Additional expansion of his electronics business to include new products and greater quantities of goods.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is a widow with two children. She runs a small pharmacy in Makeni town of Sierra Leone. She started her business in 1997 after the death of her husband. She started by selling basic medicines in a small quantity in her neighbourhood and has now expanded her business.

Being a single mother and solely responsible for providing for her family's expenses, Mary took several loans from SMT to expand her business to earn better profit. Mary now intends to expand her business to another location in Makeni called Masimra where the demand for medicines is high. She is therefore requesting a $1,200 loan to undertake this expansion.

loans.use: Expand her pharmacy to another area of Makeni town where demand is high.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es:
Sandra A., a mother of 5 children, has owned of a grocery store located in her home in the area of Villa Adela for 5 years. She stocks her store with products from well known businesses in the city. Dairy, bakery, soft drink and other companies sell their products through her store by consignment since Sandra has proven her business to be successful. She works in conjunction with her daughter, with whom she buys bulk products at commercial areas like Ceja de El Alto and other places, always weighing their cost and investment. She currently lives with her husband and children, sharing their home with her father in law. Sandra's goal is to be able to build a home on her father in law's property where she and her family can live independently and later pass onto her children.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Sandra A., madre de 5 hijos, hace 5 años es dueña de una tienda de abarrotes ubicada en su mismo domicilio de la zona de Villa Adela. Provee su tienda de empresas muy conocidas en la ciudad, empresas de lácteos, panificadoras, gaseosas y otras, dejan sus productos en consignación, puesto que Sandra tiene un negocio que se ha vuelto rentable. Trabaja conjuntamente con su hija, con quien va a realizar compras de productos al por mayor de zonas comerciales, como la Ceja de El Alto y otros lugares, siempre velando el costo y la inversión. Actualmente vive con su esposo y sus hijos, compartiendo la vivienda con el suegro. La intención de Sandra es la de poder construir dentro de la propiedad de su suegro y de esa manera independizarse con su familia, teniendo una casa propia que mas adelante podrá heredar a sus hijos.

loans.use: Sandra's goal is to be able to build a home on her father in law's property where she and her family can live independently and later pass onto her children.

loans.name: Malikie

texts.en: Malikie is married and a father of three children. He started his business fifteen years ago on a very small scale.   With previous loans from SMT he was able to expand his business.  He has been an active and honest SMT client for the last three years and has built up his own capital.  Malikie proudly said that, with the profit from his grocery store business, he can now provide his family with three meals a day.  He still needs to expand his business and build his capital further, and is requesting a $1,200 loan to do so.

loans.use: To expand the stock of his general store so as to make more sales and earn additional profit.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael T. is married and a father of four children. He runs his business with his wife and their dream is to provide their children with the best possible education. Mr. T. has been accessing credit from SMT for the last 3 years.  He used his previous loans to rent a venue for his pub business and he is now planning to expand of the business.  He is therefore requesting a loan of $1,000 for capital investment.

loans.use: Generate higher profits by offering more products to attract new customers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es:
Leonor H. H. is a married mother of two kids. She works with her husband in a micro-company dedicated to the fabrication of metal mesh used to cover damps to prevent rocks or other material from falling. They have been in business for 6 years.

Their main source of income comes from proposals they submit to the municipalities, which utilize their materials at constructions sites and others.

GAMABOL is the social reason of their company, which is one of the main suppliers of construction material in the El Alto City.

They work from their facilities at home and they purchase materials directly from the distributors who import them into the zone. They are always very careful with the quality of their products. Leonor need the capital to purchase large quantities of materials, so she can have enough to supply the new contracts that are coming their way. Their demand increases in the rainy season for obvious uses of their product to contain flooding and other rain damages.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

Leonor H. H., casada y madre de dos hijos, se dedica a trabajar con su esposo en una microempresa de su propiedad, dedicada a la fabricación de gaviones y mallas olímpicas y que administran hace ya 6 años.

Su principal actividad es la presentación a licitaciones municipales para la adjudicación de contratos de construcción y otros.

GAMABOL es la razón social de su empresa, que es una de las más importantes proveedoras de materiales de construcción en la ciudad de El Alto.

Actualmente el taller funciona dentro de su propio domicilio, y la compra de material se realiza de forma directa con empresas importadoras, cuidando siempre la calidad del acabado de los trabajos encargados. Por tal motivo, Leonor requiere de capital para poder invertir en la compra de mayor cantidad de materiales, con el fin de preparar su taller para las licitaciones próximas a lanzarse, en vista de la llegada de la temporada de lluvias.

loans.use:
Leonor wants the loan to invest in the purchase of the materials she needs, she wants to get her work area ready for the upcoming rainy season.

Leonor requiere de capital para poder invertir en la compra de mayor cantidad de materiales, con el fin de preparar su taller para las licitaciones próximas a lanzarse, en vista de la llegada de la temporada de lluvias.

loans.name: Marianela

texts.en:
Marianela is 30 years old and has one six-year-old child. She has been part of a communal bank "Bienestar II", or "Well Being II", for the last four years. During this time, she has held several positions of responsibility within the bank, such as those of the president and the secretary. 
Marianela owns a small grocery store and needs a loan of 1600 soles which she hopes to combine with the capital of her brother to buy a truck to expand their business and to transport merchandise. Through her experience with FINCA, Marianela has learned many valuable things about business, such as the importance of saving. She has also found solidarity and friendship in her bank.
Marianela’s dream is to eventually own a piece of land in Huamanga.

loans.use: Purchase of a truck to expand a business and to transport merchandise

loans.name: Delfina

texts.es:
Delfina C., a mother of 8 children, belongs to the association Escuelita 2 of Villa Adela. For three years, she has sold vegetables in the market of the 16th of July fair, where she walks long distances in order to achieve her desired number of sales. Before that, Delfina would travel to the countryside to bring back lambs which she would then work and sell in the Garita de Lima area in La Paz. For health reasons, she stopped traveling and now depends on her husband who's livelihood is heavy transport, to bring her merchandise back and forth. Depending on the season and the demand, Delfina has also sold diesel and gasoline which is a lucrative trade, but is also risky because this kind of merchandise can be confiscated and decommissioned due to new provisions established by hydrocarbon authorities. For this reason, Delfina requires capital that will allow her to seriously engage in the commerce of vegetables while taking advantage of her husband's trips in order to establish a shop in the city.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Delfina C., madre de 8 hijos, pertenece a la asociación Escuelita 2 de Villa Adela hace tres años se dedica a la venta de verduras en el mercado de la feria 16 de Julio, donde deambula largas distancias para lograr la venta esperada. Anteriormente Delfina se dedicaba a viajar al campo para traer corderos, mismos que ella misma faenaba y vendía en la zona Garita de Lima de la ciudad de La Paz. Por razones de salud, ella dejó de viajar, ahora solo deja que su esposo, quien se dedica al transporte pesado, lleve y traiga su mercadería. Dependiendo de la temporada y la demanda, en ocasiones, Delfina ha comerciado con diesel y gasolina, que si bien es un rubro muy bien remunerado, es riesgoso puesto que este tipo de mercadería puede ser confiscada y decomisada por nuevas disposiciones de las autoridades de hidrocarburos. Por tal motivo, Delfina requiere de capital que le permita activar de forma seria el comercio de verduras, aprovechando los viajes de su esposo, para poder establecer un puesto de venta en la ciudad.

loans.use: Delfina requires capital that will allow her to seriously engage in the commerce of vegetables while taking advantage of her husband's trips in order to establish a shop in the city.

loans.name: Carmen Eddy

texts.en:
Carmen is 50 years old and has five children. The youngest one is still in school, while the others already have their own families. For the last four years Carmen has been part of the Communal Bank “Bienestar II”, or “Well Being II” thanks to an invitation from her friend who had already been working with her bank for five years. Carmen has been selling groceries for the last seven years. With a loan of 3000 soles, she hopes to expand her business by adding more products like sugar, rice, soap, milk, shampoo, and other things. She will use her savings to buy a car to transport her merchandise from where she buys it to where her grocery store is located, thus saving time and money on transport. Her dream is to further develop her business and to open a second store in the jungle.
Carmen is very happy being a member of her Communal Bank. She has learned to be responsible, to be a friend to the other women in her group, and to feel like part of a sisterhood. The Communal Bank has also taught her how to take care of her children. Carmen is thankful to Morenita who was the one who taught her the value of not waiting for her husband to do something for the family, but to work herself.

loans.use: Expansion of a business through purchase of more products like sugar, rice, soap, milk, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Emerenciana

texts.en:
Emerenciana is 44 years old and has three children who are 22, 20, and 5 years old.  For the last 12 years, she has been part of the Communal Bank “Bienestar II”, or “Well Being II”.  Currently, she is the president of her bank. Emerenciana owns a transportation business with her husband, and, presently, the couple has two vehicles.  
Emerenciana desires a loan of 3000 soles. She will use the majority of her loan to open a small store in her house, and the rest to buy tires for her two vehicles.
With her savings she has been able to buy a piece of land and to build a house. In the future, she hopes to be able to add a second floor to her house and to expand her transportation business. 
Emerenciana is very happy to be part of the Communal Bank whose members can confiD. in each other. She has learned to save and to enjoy the lessons that teach her to be a better person.

loans.use: Opening of a small store, and purchase of tires for two vehicles

loans.name: Polima

texts.en: Polima is 44 years old, married and has six children. She has applied for a loan to buy ingredients for her pancake-making business. She is new to this line of work, but decided to go into business for herself after learning from the other women of her village that this is a good way to make a living. She just started her business, but can already see that this will be a good way to meet her family's needs, especially those of her children. She plans to work three days per week, and if all goes well, add a fourth day of work. She will sell her pancakes at the local school during the day and in the village in the evening, because Samoans like to eat pancakes at any time of the day . She's excited about her prospects and looks forward to applying for more loans in the future to expand her new business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for a pancake-making business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en:
Teofila has been part of the Comunal Bank Bienestar II (meaning Well-being") for the last 14 years. She is 41 years old and has four living children. Two of her children have passed away. During the time she has been part of the Communal Bank, Teofila has learned many skills from the lessons she has received. The formative lessons have made her feel increasingly more secure in her abilities. She has also been able to receive several loans from her bank.
Teofila has learned to be more punctual and to care more for her family and the people she works with.  
She has a small grocery store in her house that she has been running for the last seven years. With a loan of 1200 soles, she will be able to increase the volume of merchandise she sells, such as rice, sugar candles, soap and toilet paper. 
She has learned to save, and, with her savings, she has been able to improve her house and business.  
For example, Teofila invested a part of her savings in a motorcycle taxi for her husband's use.
Her dream is to improve her business and to save for a car, so that her husband can improve his work as a taxi driver.

loans.use: Purchase of rice, candles, soap, and paper for sale

loans.name: Selepa Elisapeta

texts.en: Selepa is 46 years old and has three children. She is a very hard-working mother who is committed to care for her family, and ensure that her children never go hungry or become beggars. She has applied for a loan to buy farm equipment and fertilizer. She sells her produce at the local town market three days a week with the help of her husband, and together they earn $84 a  day --a very good income in this part of the world. Their income helps to meet their family's needs and pay their children's school fees. If all goes well, Selepa plans to apply for another loan in the future that she will use to repair her house and provide even better living conditions for her children.

loans.use: Buy chemicals and tools for her farm

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Luse

texts.en: Luse is 35 years old and the mother of five children. She joined our program last year and applied for a loan to buy ingredients for her pancake-making business --- flour, sugar, baking powder and yeast. She runs her business five days a week because Samoans like to eat pancakes at any time, and she makes a net profit of $36 per day. She sells her pancakes at the village school during the week, and in her village market on weekends and in the evening. She uses the money she earns to buy food for her family and to pay her children's school expenses. Luse is proud of the fact that her work helps her family live better, and wants to expand her business in the future. She is very grateful for the help she receives from the SPBD program because without that support, she believes she would not have succeeded.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for a pancake-making business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Nolberta's Group

texts.en:
Maria Ernestina, Nolberta and Maria Asunta have been members of the community bank Bienestar II (meaning  “Well-being”) for two, six, and three years, respectively. Being members of the bank, they have learned skills that allow them to lead a better life. They have learned to be responsible, to communicate effectively, and to stand in solidarity.  At the same time, they have learned the value of saving.
Maria Ernestina is 53 years old and has three children. She has owned a small grocery store for the last 35 years.
Nolberta is 49 years old and has four children, all of them studying in a university. She has a small grain mill that she uses to grind many different types of flour. She sells these products from a stand in the jungle near Ayacucho. In the past, she sold these grains from a traveling cart. Over the past seven years, she has been able to save enough to buy a machine to cut the grain and another one to remove the husks.   
Maria Asunta is 56 years old and a mother of six. For the last five years, she has been running a business selling whole grains and different types of flour, such as wheat, corn, and kiwicha which is typical of the region.
Maria Ernestina, Nolberta and Maria Asunta need loans of 400 soles, 600 soles, 400 soles, respectively, which they will invest in the purchase of sugar, flour, rice, grains, and in the expansion of their respective businesses.  
They plan to use their savings to buy household items and clothing for their families.
The dream of Maria Ernestina is that her children become professionals; that of Nolberta is to further develop her business, while Maria Asunta dreams of owning a house.

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, flour, rice, grains, and expansion of business

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en: Susitina is 36 years old and has three children. She has applied for a $300 loan to buy fertilizers and tools to use on her plantation. Three days a week, she sells her produce at the local market, earning about $72 a day. She uses this money to meet her family's needs, especially those of her children. In the future, she hopes to apply for another loan which she would like to use to build a small house on the plantation, so she can keep her crops safe from thieves. She enjoys her work, especially because of the support it allows her to provide to her family.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and tools to use on a farm

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Dina Mercedes' Group

texts.en:
Irma, Sheyla, and Dina Mercedes have been part of the community bank Bienestar II (meaning “Well-being”) for the past two, one, and two years, respectively.
Being a part of the bank, they have learned many values, such as how to save, to be responsible, to collaborate, and to stand together in solidarity. They are happy with their bank and say that it brings them happiness, security, and unity. All of the associates listen to- and share their problems with- each other. Furthermore, in the lessons they participate in, they receive information about their roles as mothers, wives, and business women.  
Irma is 53 years old and has five children. She has been selling grocery items in open-air markets for the last five years.  
Sheyla is 24 years old and has an eight-month old baby. She buys clothing in Lima and afterwards sells it in the jungle near Ayacucho.  
Dina Mercedes is 39 years old and has two children. She sells avon products from her home.
Irma, Sheyla, and Dina Mercedes need loans of 600, 600, and 1200 soles, respectively, to buy groceries, clothing, and a car which will be used as a taxi. 
They plan to use their savings to buy school supplies for their children.
Irma’s dream is to build a house of solid material, Sheyla’s is to have a large store that sells shoes and clothing of every type. Dina dreams that her children will be able to finish school and find professional work.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries, clothing, and a car which will be used as a taxi

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Mrs. Magdalena has owned a taco stand for over two years. “This business is my family’s sole source of income since I’m a single mother of 3 children. I am requesting this loan in order to buy furniture for my taco stand, thus allowing me to offer better service and more comfort to my customers while they are eating. I am requesting $1,200.00 USD for the purchase of furniture for a taco stand."

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Magdalena tiene un puesto de tacos desde hace ya más de 2 años. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia ya que soy madre soltera y tengo 3 hijos. Estoy solicitando un préstamo para comprar inmobiliario para el puesto de tacos, así atender mejor a mis clientes y que estén más cómodos al consumir los alimentos. Solicito un préstamo de 1,200.00 Dlls. Para la compra de inmobiliario para el negocio de tacos.

loans.use: Purchase of furniture

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: José Dante

texts.es:
Mr. José Sanchez has had a mini market for over a year. This business is his family’s source of income. “My wife and I both work in this business. We want to buy more items and offer a wider variety of products. We are requesting a loan of $700.00 USD to buy more goods.”

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. José Dante tiene un negocio de abarrotes desde ha se ya mas de un año. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia. En el negocio trabajamos mi esposa y yo. Queremos comprar más mercancía y tener más variedad de productos. Solicitamos un préstamo de $ 700.00 Dlls para la compra de mercancía para el negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Braulio

texts.es:
I have owned a beauty salon for over two years. This is my family’s sole source of income, and I am taking care of my mother, who also works at the salon. We are in need of merchandise and equipment. We are requesting $1,000.00 USD in order to buy beauty salon equipment and merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un negocio de salón de belleza tengo ya mas de 2 años con mi negocio. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia ya que tengo a mi cargo a mi mama ella también trabaja en el negocio. Nos esta haciendo falta mercancía y unos equipos de belleza. Solicitamos un préstamo de $1,000.00 Dlls. para la compra de mercancía y equipo para el negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty salon equipment and merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Silomiga

texts.en: Silomiga is a 22-year-old mother with one child who stays at home during the day to work in her vegetable garden, which is her family's sole means of support.  She has applied for a $300 loan to buy chemicals and tools to use in her garden, and also to buy different types of vegetable seeds to plant. Silomiga sells her produce to shops in her village during the week, and in the town market on weekends. She earns about $38 a day during the week and more on weekends, but believes she can increase her income by buying the right tools, fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and tools to use in a vegetable garden

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Oliana

texts.en: Oliana is 29 years old, married and has two children. She makes a living selling ice and ice pops in her village. The ice is in especially high demand from local fisherman, who need it to preserve their catches. Oliana has applied for a loan to buy a new freezer to replace the old and worn-out one she is now using, which is also too small to keep up with the demand for ice. She's excited about the prospect of being able to meet the needs of her customers, and looks forward to using her increased income to allow the members of her family to live better lives. If all goes well, she plans to apply for another loan in the future to repair and improve her house.

loans.use: Buy a new big freezer.

payments.comment: Kiva Lenders, Oliana's loan amount was incorrectly posted on Kiva. The correct amount was properly disbursed to her using alternate funds. For that reason, no further updates will be made on the website. Your loan has been refunded. Thank you for your loan and we sincerely apologize for the error.

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
J. Dilshod is a 44-year-old single mother of three children. 

Dilshod decided to become an entrepreneur in order to support her children. She has been in business selling shoes for more than 10 years. 

She's requesting a loan of $600 so she can expand her business to generate more income. Dilshod hopes to save the additional income to help purchase an apartment for her family. She promises to repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase additional shoes to expand the business.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana A. is a 39-year-old mother who lives in the village of Sagafili Mulifanua. She is applying for a loan to buy the equipment she needs to expand her bingo parlor. She plans to use the income from this business to support her five children, all of whom are in school. Susana’s husband works as a security guard, and was the family's only source of income before his wife opened her business. Susana is a hard-working mother who runs the bingo business out of her home three nights a week, and earns about  $250 a night. The loan will allow her to expand and improve this business.

loans.use: To buy the equipment and material needed to expand a bingo parlor

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en: Mary is a 40-year-old widow with seven children. Her business is selling charcoal. She intends to use the profits from the loan to construct a storehouse where she can keep her charcoal.

loans.use: Build a storehouse for her charcoal

loans.name: Zikrillaeva

texts.en: Zikrillaeva M. lives in the Nausky region of Tajikistan with her husband and three children. She has been a Microinvest client since 2005, and is widely respected as a serious and energetic businesswoman. A school teacher by training, she now runs a small IT service that gives customers access to computers and IP telephones, and provides photocopying and printing services. She is requesting a loan of $825 to improve and expand her computer center because she believes that by doing this, she can also increase her family's income.

loans.use: To improve and expand a computer center

loans.name: Ustaev

texts.en: Ustaev A. lives in the town of Spitamen with his wife and two children. He has been a Microinvest client for the past year, and is a skillful and hard-working businessman who makes good use of his loans. Mr.Ustaev works in the food bazaar, where he sells various drinks, including juice, mineral water and coca-cola. He has come to us for a loan of $350 to expand his business and increase his family's income.

loans.use: To develop and expand a small business

loans.name: Pirnazarova

texts.en: Pirnazarova M. lives in the Nausky region of Tajikistan with her husband and three children. She has been a Microinvest client since 2006 and has proved to be a serious and highly-motivated businesswoman who has made effective use of her loans. Mrs.Pirnazarova works in the food bazaar, where she sells sweets popular with people in her area, including cookies and pies with traditional types of filling. Mrs. Pirnazarova has applied for a loan of  $475 to expand her business and continue making items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To expand her business selling candies and desserts

loans.name: Angella's Group

texts.en: Angella is 36 years old. She is a widow with six children. She sells new clothes to earn a living. She intends to use the gained profits to pay school fees for the orphans and also buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Boboeva

texts.en: Boboeva B. lives in the town of Spitamen with her husband and four children.  She has been a MicroInvest client since 2006, and is a serious and highly-motivated businesswoman who has made very effective use of several loans. Mrs.Boboeva works in the local food bazaar, where she sells vegetable oil to a wide range of customers. She has applied for a loan of $900 to expand her business and increase her family's income.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Shani's Garden Group

texts.en:
Shani, age 38, is married with a 17 year-old child. She owns a business of selling clothes in Dar es Salaam. She started this trade in 2000 and now makes a monthly profit of about $65. She works daily from 11am to 4pm selling clothes and hopes to sell more fashionable clothing in order to make a bigger profit.

Shani has taken a previous loan from BRAC Tanzania in the past in order to increase her clothing stock. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in food, drink, and timber sales.

loans.use: To buy clothing stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Kholikova

texts.en: Kholikova I. lives in the town of Spitamen with her husband and two children. She has been a Microinvest client since 2005, and has proved herself to be a reliable and effective user of our services. Mrs. Kholikova is a very experienced in her field, which is selling small items and perfume at the local bazaar. She works with a supplier who makes goods available to her at a very low price, but competition in the bazaar is very stiff. She believes that she can improve and expand her business by offering a wider assortment of goods for sale. To do this, Mrs.Kholikova has applied for a loan of $1,200.

loans.use: To expand a business and broaden the range of products it has to sell

loans.name: Shodiev

texts.en: Shodiev A. lives in the Nausky region of Tajikistan, and is married with four children. He has been a Microinvest client since 2006, and has proved himself to be a serious and highly-motivated businessman. He works in the local food bazaar, where he sells animal feed. He is very experienced in this area, because he has worked in it for the last 10 years.  Like fathers everywhere, he wants to ensure a good future for his children by giving them an education. That is why he is ready to work day and night to increase his family's income and achieve his goals. Shodiev A. has applied for a loan of $625 to improve and expand his business, and, along with it, his ability to support his family.

loans.use: To improve our business and increase our family's income

loans.name: Elizabeth's Garden Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth, age 31, is married with a 6-year-old child. She started a beauty salon just last year and works as a hairdresser. Her salon is open from 8am to 6pm daily. She is currently making a monthly profit of about $65 from this business.

Last year, Elizabeth took out a loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to open this business. She now hopes for a new loan to increase her services for her clients. She will share this loan with her subgroup who have businesses dealing in food, clothing, timber, and poultry sales.

loans.use: To expand their various businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Robinah's Group

texts.en: Robinah is 42 years old.She sells in a canteen and mainly deals with home products like soap, sugar, rice and flour. She wants to use the profits from the business to start up her own shop/ canteen.

loans.use: To increase the stock in the shop

loans.name: Robinah's Group

texts.en: Robinah is 31 years old and works as a supermarket attendant. She intends to use the profits to pay tution fees for her studies and purchase a deep freezer.

loans.use: To buy a deep freezer

loans.name: Lucy's Garden Group

texts.en:
Lucy, age 48, is the single parent of 3 children (ages 18, 20 and 22). She runs a nursery school for small children, which she started in July 1998. She works managing the school from 7:30am to 5pm daily. This business brings her a monthly profit of about $70. She has a dream of starting a primary school one day.

In the past, Lucy took out a loan to buy aluminum for the roof of the school. Having paid this loan back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan to increase her school's services. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in food, clothing, and timber sales.

loans.use: To expand businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Haji Nahim

texts.en: Haji Nahim lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with 2 sons, both married. He lives with his wife. He has a metal shop and has good experience. He has been involved in this business for more than 20 years and has lots of customers. He needs to expand his business so he requested an individual loan to complete his stock and make a good income to help both his wife and himself. He is happy with this loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Jalia's Group

texts.en: Jalia is 24yrs old and married with two children. Currently, she sells firewood to earn a living. She plans to expand her business by building a small house(kibanda) where she can keep the firewood.

loans.use: To buy more firewood

loans.name: Magdalena's Omax Group

texts.en:
Magdalena, age 27, is married with 2 children (ages 2 and 6). She and her husband also take care of their 18-year-old relative. Magdalena owns a tailoring business, which she started in 2004. She works as a seamstress from 5am to 7pm daily and makes a monthly profit of about $55 from this business.

In the past, Magdalena took a loan from BRAC Tanzania to increase her material stock for her business. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan to further expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in timber, food, and drink sales.

loans.use: To expand their various businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en: Joyce is 37 years old and divorced with four children of ages 2, 5, 7, and 10. Her current business is selling matooke in the market.. She intends to use the profits to buy a big vehicle(truck) for carrying the matooke to up countries and distant areas.

loans.use: To buy more matooke for sale

loans.name: Mwembeni C Group

texts.en:
Irene, age 42, is married with 3 children (ages 21, 15, and 12). She owns a kiosk, which she began 17 years ago. Her business is open from 9am to 10pm daily. She makes a monthly profit of about $136.

In the past, Irene took out 1 previous loan with Tujijenge Tanzania to increase on her business. She now hopes for a new loan to renovate the shop and to increase on business. She will be sharing this loan with sub group members, who have businesses dealing in selling various foods and clothes.

In the picture , Irene is second from right.

loans.use: to increase on business

payments.comment: Loan term was listed incorrectly. Loan is now finished. Tujijenge Tanzania apologizes for this mistake.

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en: Ruth would like to use the profits from her business to buy more hair dresser items.

loans.use: To buy more hair pieces, oils and weaves

loans.name: Sophia's Omax Group

texts.en:
Sophia, age 28, is married with 2 children (ages 6 and 10). She owns a small cafe where she sells breakfast and lunch foods and snacks from 5am to 6pm daily. She opened this business in 2005 and now makes a monthly profit of about $55 from it.

In the past, Sophia took out a loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy food stock for her cafe. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in sales of timber, food, and drinks.

loans.use: To buy food stock for her cafe

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Elinah's Group

texts.en: Elinah is 30 years old and is married with 6 children. She has a small retail shop. She intends to build a house from the profits made from the business.

loans.use: To purchase more juice(quencher) and increase her stock

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Mrs. Morm R., 65, is married with four children from SiemReap, Cambodia. She currently stays at home cooking food for and taking care of her family. Her husband works at a private company and generally earns only $2 each day. Two of her children must work as well, and are employed by a nearby factory while the rest of whom are married and live separately. Mrs. Morm R. hopes to acquire a loan that will enable her to purchase a motorcycle to use for her family’s transportation. Because the motor-taxi service  is too expensive for her husband and two children to go back and forth from work, she believes a motorcycle would greatly benefit her family financially. Mrs. Morm R. would also like to use the rest of the loan to open a grocery stand in her community. By doing so she hopes to make a profit and supplement her husband and children’s’ incomes in order to support their family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use for her family’s transportation

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Morm Rann start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en: Sarah is 40 years old. Her current business is selling old or used clothes. She intends to build a house and a shop from the business profits.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan N., 28, is a widow and lives with her one little children and her old-aged father in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works as a broker buying yam from the growers and resells them for a profit. She can typically make about $7 each day in revenue. Mrs. Chan N. hopes to use this loan to expand her quantity of yam to fulfill her growing customer demands. This loan will greatly help her to support her business and her family.

loans.use: To use this loan to expand her quantity of yam to fulfill her growing customer demands.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Molemo A Group

texts.en:
Salome, age 48, is married with 2 children (ages 21 and 28). She owns a clothing business and also is a food vendor. She started the clothing business in 2005 and has been selling food since 1998. She works each day from 9am to 6pm at these businesses and currently makes a monthly profit of about $330.

In the past, Salome took out a loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy inventory for her businesses. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Stella, who owns a tailoring business.

loans.use: To expand their two businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: San

texts.en: Mrs. San S., 26, works selling various kinds of grocery products to the people in her community and generally makes up to $10 a day of income. Her husband is self-employed as a barber earning $5 a day. Mrs. San S. has two children who are too young to attend school. She would like to use this loan to expand her inventory to fulfill her client’s demand as well as to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to meet her clients' needs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Bububu A Group

texts.en:
Maria is 41 years old and married with 2 children (ages 18 and 22). She sells charcoal from 6am to 7pm daily in Dar es Salaam. She began this business in 2005 and now brings in about $900 a month from her sales.

Maria took a previous loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more charcoal stock. She was able to pay this loan back successfully and now hopes for a new loan. She will share the loan with her subgroup member Maria, who owns a shop.

loans.use: To buy charcoal stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Phun

texts.en: Mrs. Phun P., 49, works with her husband on their plot of farmland growing crops and various kinds of vegetables making collectively about $5 each day. She has three children. One of them is employed at a nearby garment factory; another one is a blacksmith and the rest of are married and live separately. Mrs. Phun P. hopes to use this loan to purchase more blacksmith's supplies and other tools for her son to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase more blacksmith's supplies and other tools for her son to reinvest in his business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Changamoto Group

texts.en:
Sharifa, age 30, is married with 3 children (ages 9, 11, and 13). She has a business selling clothes, which she began 2 years ago. She works daily from 8am to 3pm and now makes a monthly profit of about $180. Her dream is to one day have a shop for her clothes business.

Sharifa hopes to take out a loan to increase her clothing inventory. She with share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in hardware and general goods.

loans.use: To expand their various businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Mrs. Ouk S. H., 37,is married with two school-aged children. She currently earns a living by selling rice and Khmer food for which she makes about a $2 profeit each day. Her husband drives a taxi and typically earns around $3 each day. Mrs. Ouk S. H. and her husband would like to raise their standard of living by selling fish to a number of venders at a market, yet she faces a financial constraint to do so. She has humbly applied for a loan to purchase a car so she can buy fish from a port fishery and carry it back to town to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a car to transport fish

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Changamoto B Group

texts.en:
Zainab, age 32, is married with 2 children (ages 15 and 10). She is a shopkeeper and sells general items every day from 4am to 6pm. She opened this business 2 years ago and now makes a monthly profit of about $180 from her sales.

Zainab hopes for a loan to buy more stock for her shop. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in clothing and snacks sales.

loans.use: To expand their various businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Uamsho Group

texts.en:
Aruna, age 35, is married with 3 children (ages 12, 9, and 5). She has a business selling timber that she started three years ago. She works from 9am to 3pm daily and now makes a monthly profit of about $280.

Aruna hopes to get a loan in order to increase her stock of timber. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in clothing, livestock, food, and firewood sales.

loans.use: To buy timber stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Lek

texts.en: Mrs. Lek H., 56, is a widow with five children and lives with her other two grand children in a part of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She can only make meager money each day from selling the harvest of her rice crops and vegetables which she grows on her piece of land. Meanwhile, one of her children works selling Khmer food and rice in a town of Kampong Cham and another one is self-employed as a construction foreman and the rest of whom are married and live separately. Mrs. Leak H. is requesting a loan to purchase more construction tools for her son to make his work more convenient and effective.

loans.use: To purchase more construction tools for her son to make his work more convenient and effective.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Uamsho B Group

texts.en:
Daines, age 45, is married with 4 children (ages 20, 17, 14, and 10). She owns a business selling general property supplies, which she began a year ago. She works from 8am to 4pm daily and now makes a monthly profit of about $150 from her business.

Daines hopes to take out a loan to increase her inventory for her sales. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have a beauty parlor, a tailor shop, and general goods businesses.

loans.use: To expand their various businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Usalama Wa Pesa Group

texts.en: Selamani M. K.. Bakari A. Wahura, Tadei M. M., Mohamedi M. Kidili, Maimuma J. K., Sada K., Aruna N. and Fukirini R. are members of the Usalama wa Pesa group, in Vingunguti market in Dar Es Salaam city. Their businesses are located in Vingunguti municipal market and include fruit and vegetable sales, kiosks, small restaurants, and shops. They are jointly in need of US$ 3200, or US$ 400 each, to help them boost their businesses.

loans.use: expand their various businesses

loans.name: Suriya's Group

texts.en: I am Suriya L. Ali. I have lived all my life in the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. I have five children: four boys and one girl. My eldest son is a truck driver, my second son works in a hotel, and the youngest two are tailors. My daughter is married. My husband is a farmer and works on someone else's fields on contract; he also keeps a few cows on his field. Now, I would like to buy an additional cow for my husband. The loans that we took out earlier helped us expand our business and construct a brick house for our family. I am the leader of a group of several women; we formed our loan group three years ago. My group members are: Koser B. needs a loan for their grocery store, Haneefan B. requires a loan for their restaurant, Sughran B. wants to invest loan in her embroidery business. All these women are very hardworking entrepreneurs and play an important part in supplementing the family income.

loans.use: Buy an additional cow

loans.name: Hameedan's Group

texts.en: My name is Hameedan B.. I have lived  in the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan, for the last 15 years. I am a widow with five children: three boys and two girls. All my kids are currently working. Our financial outlook earlier was very poor, and that is why my kids could not attend school. Now, my son would like a loan to buy a donkey cart from which to sell vegetables. There are two other loan members in my group:  Farhat B. needs a loan for her milk and yogurt business. Rani B. will also use the loan to buy a donkey cart.

loans.use: Buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Naziran's Group

texts.en: I live in the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan, with my family. I have eight kids: five girls and three boys. Currently, three of my kids attend school. My husband manufactures stitching machines. He has hired one worker to help him in the business. Now, we need a loan to invest in our business. My other group members are: Mariam B. needs a loan for their grocery. Shamshad B. needs a loan to buy cloth for her embroidery business. Rehahna B. needs a loan for their thread and second-hand clothing business. Khursheed B. wants a loan to buy thread for their tailoring business. Rubina B. needs this loan for their cosmetics and jewelry store. All these women really deserve loans and work very hard to expand their businesses.

loans.use: Expand current business

loans.name: Munnawer's Group

texts.en: I am Munnawer B. from the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. I am married and have a daughter who is one and half years old. My husband repairs electronics and I embroider clothes for the women in my neighborhood. My husband would like to expand his business, and we're asking for a loan for that purpose. He has been in this business for many years. My group members are: Shamshad B. runs an embroidery business. Bano B. needs a loan for her son’s electronics store. Suriya B. will buy an electric sewing machine for her embroidery business. Enayat B. needs a loan for their second-hand store. These members are very cooperative and are honest in their dealings.

loans.use: Expand electronics store

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
I am Zubaida B. from the small town Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. I live in a two-room brick house with my husband and kids. I have nine in all: Four of them are married and live on their own, and five still live with us. My husband was the only breadwinner in the family and we did not have enough to send all our kids to school. My husband is a day laborer and now wants to start a business selling fruits and vegetables. We would use the loan to start the business and also to add a floor to my house, currently it is a single-story building. My group members are: Vero R. needs a loan for her business of selling crops wholesale. Kaneez F. requires a loan for her son’s fruit business. 
Please lend us this money so that we can improve the lives of our families.

loans.use: Start  a business selling frutis and vegetables

loans.name: Allah's Group

texts.en: I am Allah R., wife of Muhammad Yasin. I have six children: three boys and three girls. My husband sells crockery on his cart in exchange for money or used items. He earns $3 to $4 a day. I embroider clothes to order for one of my relatives. My husband now plans to expand his business and requires a loan for this purpose. Earlier, we invested a loan in this business, and our profits increased so that we could repair our house. My group members are: Waziran B. requires a loan for her dairy business. Sharifan B. needs a loan for her grocery store. Zarina B. plans to use her loan for her dairy business. Koser B. wants a loan to buy a cow. Jameela B. wants a loan to expand her beauty parlor.

loans.use: Expand crockery business

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en: My name is Naseem A. H.. I am married and have seven children: four boys and three girls. Currently, three of my kids attend school. I have lived all my life in Kot Radha Kishan, a small town in Pakistan. My husband is a butcher and sells meat. Along with this he also sells livestock. Currently, we require a loan to buy a cow. I have few other women in my loan group. Rukkiah B. needs a loan for her dairy business. Jameela B. plans to use this loan for her crockery business. Salma B. requires a loan to buy a cow. Tahira B. also plans to buy a cow. All the members in my loan group are very responsible and cooperate with me in every unit meeting.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en: I live with my family in Kot Radha Kishan, a small town in Pakistan since my birth. I am married and a mother of three: two girls and one boy. My kids are small and attend school except one girl who is small and will attend school in future. My husband is a day laborer and I sell and stitch blanket covers. I buy cloth in bulk for this business; my business is at its best in winter due to its high demand. My husband and brother also help me in this business. Last year, I invested a loan of $230 in this business. This year I plan another loan for this business.I am a group leader of few other women: Sughran B. needs a loan to invest in their milk business. Razia B. wants a loan to buy a  donkey cart.  Sufia B. has a tyres shop and wants a loan to improve it.I want these women to receive loans so that they can bring positive changes in their financial conditions.

loans.use: Expand blankets covers production

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Enayatan's Group

texts.en: I have six children: three boys and three girls. I live with my family in the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. All of my kids attend school. I enrolled my kids in school because I am not educated, and I do not want the same fate for my kids. My husband makes and sells wooden doors and cupboards. He employs five workers. Last year we took out a loan to buy a saw. This year we would like to buy a wood cutting machine for which we require a loan. My group members are: Haneefan B., Fozia B., Bashiran B., and Zubaida B.. They would use the money to buy cows for their dairy business.

loans.use: Buy a wood cutting machine

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.use: To expand her business

texts.en:
Joweria is 40 years old. She sells used clothes for her income. She plans to 
construct a poultry house from the profits from her business.

loans.use: To expand her clothe selling business

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 38-year-old Veronica M.. She is married with two children, aged 16 and 20.

In 2005, Veronica established a café business. Veronica has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $900 in order to purchase additional ingredients and cooking equipment in bulk.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling.

Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be.

The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients and cooking equipment in bulk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Hadija's Group

texts.en: Hadija is 43 years old and is married with nine children. Her current business is selling charcoal. She intends to venture into selling used shoes after acquiring profits.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Tuli

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 46-year-old Tuli Kibuga. She is single with four children, aged 15, 19, 22, and 24.

In 2002, Tuli established a food stall. Tuli has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $550 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice and dried fish.

It is the kind of place where local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of fruit and vegetables, rice, oil and fish in bulk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mery

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 47-year-old Mery B.. She is married with six children, aged between 16 and 31.

In 2002, Mery established a poultry business, and now requires a loan of $275 in order to purchase additional chicks to raise and sell.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. "Who or what are ‘kuku?’," you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons.

First, they require little start-up capital, you can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiply naturally!

Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound.

Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks to raise and sell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 30-year-old Neema M.. She is married with one child, aged 7.

In 2004, Neema established a tailoring business. Neema has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $550 in order to purchase an extra sewing machine, cloth, buttons, needles and zippers.

Neema is a perfect example of why microfinance works and why the large majority of clients repay their loans. A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or kiva.org) for the first time, ask anxiously, “but how do you make sure people pay back? Won’t they just take the money?”

The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually the ‘poor’) are less trustworthy, efficient or educated than ‘ordinary’ people. Whether or not this is true is somewhat irrelevant, for a number of reasons.

First, most MFIs have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk.

More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive.

The incentive clients have to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another…The incentive to have ongoing access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

Neema is in the center of the picture, sitting between two of her apprentices.

loans.use: To purchase an additional sewing machine, material, buttons, needles and zippers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Namsifu

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 32-year-old Namsifu M.. She is married with two children, aged 4 and 13, and has two other dependents, who are her niece and nephew.

In 2007, Namsifu established a retail business. Namsifu has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $550 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
Claudia lives at 482 Chavarria Street in a neighborhood called Satelite, which is located in the city of El Alto. She lives there with her two children, ages three and one. Her husband works at an institution in the city of Santa Cruz. Claudia works as a hairdresser from her home, in an area converted for her to work. She would like this loan in order to buy more material, such as dyes, hair developer, combs and brushes, etc. This is her second loan with Impro, and her evaluation qualifies her for this loan request.

Translated from Spanish by Mindy Burns, Kiva volunteer

Claudia vive Calle Chavarria plan 482 de la zona Ciudad Satélite, ubicada en la ciudad de El Alto. Vive junto a sus dos hijos de 3 y 1 año respectivamente, su esposo trabaja en una institución en la ciudad de Santa Cruz..Trabaja como peinadora en una habitación adaptada para su actividad en su domicilio. El crédito lo destinara en la compra de material - tintes, Developer, peines, etc., para desempeñar su trabajo. Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase dyes, hair developer, and brushes for her beauty salon business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
Andrea lives on Mundo Street in a neighborhood called Villa Exaltacion, which is located on the outskirts of the city of El Alto. She is a single mother and lives with her ten year old daughter. She makes a living by selling spices and peppers at a market located in the central part of the city. She would like to use this loan in order to purchase a larger variety of spices and peppers, therefore increasing her sales and earnings. This is her first loan with Impro, and her evaluation qualifies her for this loan request.

Translated from Spanish by Mindy Burns, Spanish volunteer

Andrea vive en la calle Mundo de la zona Villa Exaltación la cual se ubica en la periferie de la ciudad de El Alto. Vive junto a su hija de 10 años pues la señora es madre soltera. Se dedica al la venta de condimentos y ajíes en un mercado de la zona central de la ciudad. El crédito lo destinara en la compra (condimentos y ajíes de diferente calidad) de mercadería y así incrementar sus ventas y por lo tanto sus ingresos. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise, including spices and peppers

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.ru:
Dilafruz J. is 27 years old and has a high school education. She is single. Dilafruz sells children's items, men's and women's pants, women's and children's shoes, and some other goods. She has been in business for 8 years and has a trading point at Yavan's central market.

She plans to use her loan to buy a new selection of winter goods. The loan will allow her to expand her inventory and meet demand, which is higher in winter. The residents of Yavan region will have the opportunity to get necessary winter clothing at reasonable prices, since they won't have to travel to Dushanbe (the capital) to buy the same goods, losing time and money. Dilafruz plans to repay her loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Джугиемва Дилафруз, возраст – 27 лет, образование среднее, не замужем. Дилафруз занимается продажей детских вещей, мужских и женских брюк, женских и детских туфлей, а также другого товара. Этим видом деятельности она занимается уже в течение 8 лет. Она имеет торговую точку на центральном рынке города Явана под навзванием «Тиджорат». На полученный кредит она планирует приобрести новый ассортимент зимнего товара. Данный кредит поможет ей увеличить ассортимент продаваемого товара, так как в зимний период на него возрос спрос, а также жители Яванского района получат возможность приобретать необходимые им зимние товары по умеренным ценам, при этом им не надо будет ездить в город Душанбе за аналогичным товаром, при этом теряя своё время и денежные средства. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: to purchase new seasonal goods

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Miguel A.

texts.es:
Miguel raises cattle which produces milk for PIL (local milk producing plant). He lives in the Nina Chiri community, Lajas sector. This is three hours away from La Paz. He is a single man who lives with his grandmother and three younger siblings. He offers financial support since he's the oldest one in the house.

He will use the money to purchase more cattle and thus increase milk production. This is his first credit with Impro, the evaluation he got qualified him for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Miguel cría ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche la comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadora de Leche). Vive en la Comunidad de Nina Chiri sector Laja a tres horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz., El es soltero vive junto a su abuela y a sus tres hermanos menores a quienes colabora económicamente por ser el hermano mayor. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de ganado de raza mejorada y así incrementar la producción de leche. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Kurbonoy

texts.ru:
Kurbonoy K. is 41 years old and has a high school education. She is married with two children. Kurbonoy sells national fabrics, scarves, women's shoes, and other goods. She has been in business for seven years. She rents a trading point called "Tidjorat" at Yavan's central market. She plans to use her loan to buy more inventory, specifically new headscarves, which are worn by local residents, and also new fabric for sewing the national dress. This loan will help local women obtain their necessary headwear and cloth, since the majority of women in this region wear the national dress. Kurbonoy plans to repay her loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Каримоива Курбоной, возраст – 41 год, образование среднее, замужем, имеет 2-х детей. Курбоной занимается торговлей национальными тканями, национальными платками, женскими туфлями и другими товарами. Она занимается этим бизнесом уже в течение 7 лет. Для этого она арендует торговую точку на центральным рынке города Явана под названием «Тиджорат». На полученный кредит она планирует приобрести новый ассортимент продаваемого товара, а именно новые платки, которыми укрывают головы местные жители, новые ткани для пошива национальной одежды. Данный кредит поможет местным женщинам приобретать необходимые им головные уборы, а также женские ткани, так как большинство женщин данного района придерживаются национального стиля одежды. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: to obtain new goods and expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mastura

texts.ru:
Mastura Z. is 40 years old, has a secondary education, is married and has 2 children. Mastura has been in business for 13 years. She sells her goods at the “Tidjarat” market in the Yavan region. Her main products are national fabrics to make national women’s clothing and warm winter clothing.

Mastura will use her loan to purchase new products for sale and to expand her business. This loan will help local residents to acquire necessary clothing at reasonable prices. Mastura will pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Purchase porducts for sale and expand business

loans.name: Jhonny

texts.es:
Jhonny has been back from Brazil for six months, here he worked as a tailor next to his wife; he returned to Bolivia in order to care for their young child. He works on his own making clothes, this is their main source of income. They live in the Villa Santa Rosa zone of El Alto city.

The credit he requests is to purchase a sewing machine which will help him keep up with the demands of his job.

This is his first credit with Impro, the evaluation he received allowed him to get the necessary credit.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Jhonny hace 6 meses que volvió de Brasil donde trabajo como costurero junto a su esposa; por el bienestar de su pequeño hijo retornaron a Bolivia para trabajar por cuenta propia como confeccionistas de prendas de vestir, siendo esta actividad su principal fuente de ingreso con que cubre la manutención de su familia; vive en la Zona Villa Santa Rosa de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito requiere para comprar una maquina recta de coser misma que le ayudara para satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que tiene en su mercado. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobar el préstamo solicitado por Jhonny.

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine for his workshop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Karim

texts.ru:
Karim K., who is 33, has a post secondary technical degree, is married, and has 2 children. During the past 10 years, Karim has been in the business of selling materials for traditional women's clothing on the central market of Yavan city called "Tijorat". He plans to use funds from the loan to increase the assortment of his inventory. Since the products that he sells are used in the women's clothing, these materials are in high demand and need to be constantly renewed. The obtained loan will give local women an opportunity to purchase needed textiles at moderate prices. Karim is planning to pay off the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Кузиев Карим, возраст – 33 года, образование среднее-техничесткое, женат, имеет 2-х детей. Карим в течение 10 лет занимается торговлей национальными тканями на центарльном рынке города Явана, под названием «Тиджорат». Полученный кредит клиент планирует использовать на приобретение нового ассортимента продаваемого товара. Так как продаваемый товар это женский национальный материал для пошива женской одежды он пользуется большим спрсом и требует постоянног обновления. Полученный кредит даст возможность местным женщинам приобретать необходимый им материал по их вкусу по умеренным ценам. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Rocio A.

texts.es:
Rocio is a street vendor who sells goods and ladies clothes. Her husband works in the city and comes home every three months. They have one child, their main source of income is the business that Rocio has. She's been able to maintain her one year old child this way; they live in the Munaypata zone of La Paz city.

The credit will be used to increase her goods and therefore increase their earnings.

This is her second credit with Kiva and Impro; the evaluation has qualified her for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson.

Roció es comerciante ambulante de víveres y ropa para damas, el esposo trabaja en el interior del país y llega cada tres meses. Ellos tienen un hijo, su principal fuente de ingresos es por la actividad comercial que tiene Roció con la que mantiene a su pequeño niño de un año; vive en la Zona de Munaypata de la Ciudad de La Paz. El crédito lo destinara para incrementar su mercadería y así generar mayores ingresos familiares. Es el segundo crédito con KIVA e Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle otro préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase of goods and clothes for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ayubu's Group

texts.en: Ayubu G., Mrisho H.,, Saidi M., Hasumani M., Paulo J. and Salehe S., are, are six members of the Mwanzo group. They have been with Youth self employment foundation for the past five months. They carry out their businesses in Vingunguti area(most known for butchery activities, mainly goats)  , a Dar Es Salaam suburb and at least almost all have been in business for the past five years. Their businesses run from butchery, restaurants and kiosks. They are jointly in need of USD 2400, in which each is top take USD 400, to help them expand their business.

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Beltran

texts.es:
Mr. Beltran lives in his own house in the San Juan Villa in the city of La Paz with his wife and two children. Mr. Beltran is a police officer and his wife is a homemaker.

With former loans, Mr. Beltran was able to build his two story home. His family lives in the lower level of the house.

The loan requested will be used to complete the upper level of his house, he wants to build two bedrooms in the upper level. This is the tenth time he requests a loan. The socioeconomic review done generously qualifies him for a loan.

In Bolivia, houses are usually done in sections because people are poor and they don't have the capital to build it all at one time.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Beltrán C. vive en casa propia en la zona de Villa San Juan de la Ciudad de La Paz con su esposa y sus dos hijos. El señor Beltrán presta sus servicios como oficial de policía y su esposa es ama de casa. Con anteriores créditos el señor Beltrán realizó la construcción de su vivienda en dos plantas, de las cuales el nivel inferior esta concluido y la ocupa la familia. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción en obra fina y acabado de dos habitaciones en planta alta. Esta es la décima ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito. En Bolivia, la construcción de una casa cuyo dueño es gente pobre, se hace casi siempre por partes, pues los dueños no tienen el capital suficiente para construir completamente la casa y de una sola vez.

loans.use: Completion of two bedrooms

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Wilma

texts.es:
Mrs. Wilma F. lives in her own house with her husband and their four children in the town of Tupac Amaru in the city La Paz. She runs a neighborhood shop from out of her home and her husband works as the chauffeur of a public taxi.

The rooms that they live in are in a precarious condition for no being supported with the proper structures. For this reason there is a permanent risk. The requested loan will be used to demolish this room and build two new ones. This is the third time that Mrs. Wilma F. solicits a loan and a socioeconomic analysis qualifies them for it.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Wilma F. vive en casa propia en la zona de Tupac Amaru de la Ciudad de La Paz con su esposo, el señor Enrrique Quispe y sus cuatro hijos. La señora Wilma tiene una tienda de barrio en su domicilio y su esposo trabaja como chofer de un taxi publico. Las habitaciones que ocupan se encuentran en condiciones precarias por no contar con estructuras apropiadas y el riesgo es permanente. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la demolición de una habitación y la construcción de estructuras nuevas para dos habitaciones.
